meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

longTitle.name: longTitle
longTitle.content: An Ordinance to consolidate and amend the law relating to financial products, the securities and futures market and the securities and futures industry, the regulation of activities and other matters connected with financial products, the securities and futures market and the securities and futures industry, the protection of investors, and other matters incidental thereto or connected therewith, and for connected purposes.

section.name: s1
section.heading: Short title

subsection.content: This Ordinance may be cited as the Securities and Futures Ordinance.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation

subsection.content: Schedule 1 contains interpretation provisions which apply to this Ordinance in accordance with their terms.
Individual Parts and provisions of this Ordinance contain interpretation provisions which have application in accordance with their terms.
The Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Parts 2, 3, 4 and 5 of Schedule 1.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Securities and Futures Commission

subsection.content: Notwithstanding the repeal of the Securities and Futures Commission Ordinance (Cap. 24) under section 406, the body established by section 3 of that Ordinance as the Securities and Futures Commission shall continue in existence in its original name as a body corporate with power to sue and be sued in that name.

Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, the corporate identity of the Commission, and the rights, privileges, powers, obligations and liabilities of the Commission and those of others in relation to the Commission, are not affected by the repeal of the Securities and Futures Commission Ordinance (Cap. 24) under section 406, and any reference to the Commission (whether by reference to that Ordinance or otherwise) in any Ordinance or any instrument, record or document, or in or for the purposes of any proceedings, agreement or arrangement (whether in writing or not) shall be construed accordingly.
The receipts of the Commission are not subject to taxation under the Inland Revenue Ordinance (Cap. 112).
Part 1 of Schedule 2 contains provisions relating to the constitution and proceedings of and other matters relating to the Commission.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Regulatory objectives of Commission
section.leadIn: The regulatory objectives of the Commission are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to maintain and promote the fairness, efficiency, competitiveness, transparency and orderliness of the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to promote understanding by the public of financial services including the operation and functioning of the securities and futures industry; (Replaced 9 of 2012 s. 30)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to provide protection for members of the public investing in or holding financial products;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to minimize crime and misconduct in the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to reduce systemic risks in the securities and futures industry; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to assist the Financial Secretary in maintaining the financial stability of Hong Kong by taking appropriate steps in relation to the securities and futures industry.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Functions and powers of Commission

subsection.leadIn: The functions of the Commission are, so far as reasonably practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to take such steps as it considers appropriate to maintain and promote the fairness, efficiency, competitiveness, transparency and orderliness of the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to supervise, monitor and regulate—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the activities carried on by recognized exchange companies, recognized clearing houses, recognized exchange controllers or recognized investor compensation companies, or by persons carrying on activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions, other than registered institutions; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such of the activities carried on by registered institutions as are required to be regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to promote and develop an appropriate degree of self-regulation in the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to promote, encourage and enforce the proper conduct, competence and integrity of persons carrying on activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions in the conduct of such activities;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: to encourage the provision of sound, balanced and informed advice regarding transactions or activities related to financial products;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to take such steps as it considers appropriate to ensure that the relevant provisions are complied with;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: to maintain and promote confidence in the securities and futures industry in such manner as it considers appropriate, including by the exercise of its discretion to disclose to the public any matter relating or incidental to the performance of any of its functions;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: to co-operate with and provide assistance to regulatory authorities or organizations, whether formed or established in Hong Kong or elsewhere;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: to enhance the understanding and knowledge of members of the public of financial services including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the operation and functioning of the securities and futures industry; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the benefits, risks and liabilities associated with purchasing financial services including investing in financial products; (Replaced 9 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to encourage the public to appreciate the relative benefits of purchasing different types of financial services including investing in financial products through persons carrying on activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions; (Amended 9 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.leadIn: to promote understanding by the public of the importance of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: making informed decisions regarding the purchasing of financial services and transactions and activities related to financial products; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: taking responsibility for those decisions; (Replaced 9 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: to secure an appropriate degree of protection for members of the public investing in or holding financial products, having regard to their degree of understanding and expertise in respect of investing in or holding financial products;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.leadIn: to promote, encourage and enforce—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the adoption of appropriate internal controls and risk management systems by persons carrying on activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions, other than registered institutions; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the adoption of appropriate internal controls and risk management systems by registered institutions in the conduct of activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: to suppress illegal, dishonourable and improper practices in the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: to take appropriate steps in relation to the securities and futures industry further to any requirement of the Financial Secretary for the purpose of providing assistance in maintaining the financial stability of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: p
paragraph.content: to recommend reforms of the law relating to the securities and futures industry;

paragraph.name: q
paragraph.content: to advise the Financial Secretary on matters relating to the securities and futures industry and provide him with such information in relation thereto as it considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: r
paragraph.content: to perform functions conferred or imposed on it by or under this or any other Ordinance.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(c) does not limit or otherwise affect any other function of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission, in performing any of its functions in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any authorized financial institution as a registered institution or as an associated entity of an intermediary; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person as an associated entity of an authorized financial institution that is a registered institution,

subsection.continued: may rely, in whole or in part, on the supervision of such authorized financial institution or person (as the case may be) by the Monetary Authority.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance, the Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: acquire, hold and dispose of property of any description;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make contracts or other agreements;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: receive and expend moneys;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: with the approval of the Financial Secretary, borrow money on security or other conditions;

paragraph.name: da
paragraph.content: establish a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commission to facilitate the performance of functions under subsection (1)(i), (j) and (k); (Added 9 of 2012 s. 31)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: publish or otherwise make available materials (however described) indicating to persons who are, or who carry on activities, regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions and, where the Commission considers appropriate, to any other persons the manner in which, in the absence of any particular consideration or circumstance, the Commission proposes to perform any of its functions; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: publish or otherwise make available materials (however described) indicating to the public any matter relating or incidental to the performance of any of the functions of the Commission.

subsection.content: Materials published or otherwise made available under subsection (4)(e) or (f) are not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s6
section.heading: General duties of Commission

subsection.leadIn: In performing its functions, the Commission shall, so far as reasonably practicable, act in a way which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is compatible with its regulatory objectives; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it considers most appropriate for the purpose of meeting those objectives.

subsection.leadIn: In pursuing its regulatory objectives and performing its functions, the Commission shall have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the international character of the securities and futures industry and the desirability of maintaining the status of Hong Kong as a competitive international financial centre;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the desirability of facilitating innovation in connection with financial products and with activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the principle that competition among persons carrying on activities regulated by the Commission under any of the relevant provisions should not be impeded unnecessarily;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the importance of acting in a transparent manner, having regard to its obligations of preserving secrecy and confidentiality; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the need to make efficient use of its resources.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Advisory Committee

subsection.content: There shall be an Advisory Committee to advise the Commission on matters of policy regarding any of its regulatory objectives and functions.
The Advisory Committee is constituted in accordance with Part 1 of Schedule 2 and shall conduct its business in accordance with that Part.
The Advisory Committee shall meet at least once every 3 months to advise the Commission.
The Commission may request the Advisory Committee to advise it on matters of policy regarding any of its regulatory objectives and functions.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Commission may establish committees

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may establish—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: standing committees; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: special committees.

subsection.content: The Commission may refer a matter to a committee established under this section for consideration, inquiry or management.

The Commission may appoint a person to be a member of a committee established under this section, whether or not the person is a member of the Commission, and may appoint a member of the committee to be the chairman of the committee.
A reference of a matter to a committee under subsection (2) does not prevent the Commission from performing any of its functions.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: withdraw a reference under subsection (2) from a committee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: revoke an appointment of a member or chairman of a committee under subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: A committee established under this section may elect one of its members—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be its chairman if a chairman has not been appointed by the Commission under subsection (3); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to act as its chairman for any period during which a chairman appointed by the Commission under subsection (3) is unable to act as chairman due to illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause,

subsection.continued: and may at any time remove the member so elected from the office of the chairman.

subsection.content: A committee established under this section may, subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, regulate its own procedure and business.

A committee established under this section shall meet when and where the chairman of the committee determines, subject to any procedure fixed by the committee and any direction given by the Commission under subsection (9).

The Commission may give directions to a committee established under this section, whether generally or in any particular case, and whether regarding the manner in which it shall act or otherwise, and the committee shall act in accordance with any such directions.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Staff of Commission

subsection.content: The Commission may employ persons for such remuneration and allowances, and on such other terms and conditions, as the Commission determines.
The Commission may provide and maintain schemes (whether contributory or not) for the payment of retirement benefits, gratuities or other allowances to its employees and their dependants.
The Commission may engage consultants, agents and advisers to assist it in the performance of its functions.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Delegation and sub-delegation of Commission’s functions

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the Commission may delegate any of its functions to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a member of the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a committee established under section 8; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an employee of the Commission, whether by reference to his name or to the office held by him.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The Commission may delegate any of its functions under section 5(1)(i), (j) or (k) to a wholly owned subsidiary established under section 5(4)(da). (Added 9 of 2012 s. 32)

subsection.leadIn: No delegation shall be made under subsection (1) in respect of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the power of the Commission to delegate under this section; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a function specified in Part 2 of Schedule 2.

subsection.name: 2AA
subsection.leadIn: However, subsection (2)(b) does not prevent a function specified in Part 3 of Schedule 2 from being delegated to the chief executive officer of the Commission for the purpose of the application of a stabilization option under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance (Cap. 628) to any of the following— (Amended E.R. 2 of 2017)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a recognized clearing house;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a holding company (within the meaning of that Ordinance) or affiliated operational entity of an entity mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b). (Added 23 of 2016 s. 215)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.content: The Commission may delegate any of its functions under section 17 (investment of funds) or 241 (investment of money forming part of the compensation fund) to a consultant, agent or adviser engaged by the Commission under section 9(3). (Added 9 of 2012 s. 37)

Where the Commission delegates a function under this section, it may at the same time authorize the delegate to sub-delegate the function and the authorization may contain restrictions or conditions on the exercise of the power to sub-delegate.
A delegation or sub-delegation under this section does not prevent the Commission or its delegate from concurrently performing the function delegated or sub-delegated.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: revoke a delegation under this section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: revoke an authorization in respect of a sub-delegation under this section,

subsection.continued: whereupon the delegation or sub-delegation (as the case may be) shall cease to have effect.

subsection.content: Where a person or committee purports to act pursuant to a delegation or sub-delegation under this section, he or it shall be presumed, unless the contrary is proved, to be acting in accordance with the terms of the delegation or sub-delegation.

Without prejudice to subsection (4), where there is a delegation or sub-delegation under this section in respect of a function of the Commission, any reference in this or any other Ordinance to the Commission in connection with the performance of the function shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be construed accordingly.
The Legislative Council may by resolution amend Part 2 or 3 of Schedule 2. (Amended 23 of 2016 s. 215)

section.name: s11
section.heading: Directions to Commission

subsection.content: After consultation with the chief executive officer of the Commission, the Chief Executive may, upon being satisfied that it is in the public interest to do so, give the Commission written directions as to the furtherance of any of its regulatory objectives or the performance of any of its functions. (Amended 15 of 2006 s. 2)
The Commission shall comply with any written direction given under subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: Where any written direction is given under subsection (1), any requirement under any other provision of this or any other Ordinance that the Commission shall, for the purpose of performing any of the functions to which the written direction relates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: form any opinion;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be satisfied as to any matter (including existence of particular circumstances); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: consult any person,

subsection.continued: shall not apply for all purposes connected with the performance of functions pursuant to, or consequent upon, the written direction.

subsection.content: Written directions given under subsection (1) are not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Commission to furnish information
section.content: The Commission shall, when required by the Financial Secretary, furnish to the Financial Secretary such information as he specifies on the principles, practices and policy it is pursuing or adopting, or proposes to pursue or adopt, in furthering any of its regulatory objectives or performing any of its functions, and the reasons therefor.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Financial year and estimates

subsection.content: The financial year of the Commission commences on 1 April in each year.

The Commission shall, not later than 31 December in each financial year of the Commission, submit to the Chief Executive for his approval estimates of its income and expenditure for the next financial year.
The Financial Secretary shall cause the estimates as approved pursuant to subsection (2) to be laid on the table of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s14
section.heading: Appropriation
section.content: For each financial year of the Commission, the Government shall pay to the Commission out of the general revenue the moneys appropriated by the Legislative Council for that purpose.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Accounts and annual report

subsection.content: The Commission shall keep proper accounts and records of its transactions.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after the end of each financial year of the Commission, prepare financial statements which shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give a true and fair view of the state of affairs of the Commission as at the end of the financial year and of the results of its operations and cash flows in the financial year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be signed by the chairman and the chief executive officer of the Commission. (Amended 15 of 2006 s. 3)

subsection.content: The Commission shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after the end of each financial year of the Commission, prepare a report on its activities during the financial year and send a copy of the report to the Financial Secretary who shall cause a copy thereof to be laid on the table of the Legislative Council.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Auditors and audit

subsection.content: The Commission shall, with the approval of the Financial Secretary, appoint auditors.

The Commission shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after the end of each financial year of the Commission, submit to the auditors appointed under subsection (1) for audit the financial statements prepared for the financial year under section 15(2).

The auditors appointed under subsection (1) shall prepare a report on the financial statements submitted to them under subsection (2) and send the report to the Commission which shall, as soon as reasonably practicable after its receipt, send to the Financial Secretary a copy of the report and a copy of the financial statements to which the report relates.

The auditors appointed under subsection (1) shall include in their report a statement as to whether, in their opinion, the financial statements to which the report relates give a true and fair view of the state of affairs of the Commission as at the end of the financial year for which the financial statements are prepared and of the results of its operations and cash flows in the financial year.

An auditor appointed under subsection (1) has a right of access at all reasonable times to the books, accounts, vouchers, records and documents kept by the Commission and is entitled to require from the officers of the Commission such information and explanations as he considers necessary for the performance of his duties as auditor.

The Financial Secretary shall cause a copy of the report referred to in subsection (3), and a copy of the financial statements to which the report relates, to be laid on the table of the Legislative Council.

subsection.leadIn: The Director of Audit or another public officer authorized by the Director under subsection (8) may at any reasonable time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: examine any books, accounts, vouchers, records or documents kept by the Commission; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the Director or the public officer (as the case may be) considers appropriate, make a copy of the whole of, or any entry in, such books, accounts, vouchers, records or documents.

subsection.content: The Director of Audit may authorize any public officer to perform any function for the purposes of subsection (7).

section.name: s17
section.heading: Investment of funds
section.content: The Commission may invest its funds which are not immediately required in the manner that the Financial Secretary approves.

part.name: P3
part.heading: Exchange Companies, Clearing Houses, Exchange Controllers, Investor Compensation Companies and Automated Trading Services

section.name: s18
section.heading: Interpretation of Part III

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—

def.name: AssociatedPerson
def.leadIn: associated person (相聯者), in relation to a person entitled to exercise, or control the exercise of, voting power in relation to, or holding securities in, a corporation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), means any other person in respect of whom that first-mentioned person has an agreement or arrangement, whether oral or in writing, express or implied, with respect to the acquisition, holding or disposal of securities or other interests in that corporation or under which they act together in exercising their voting power in relation to it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (c), includes, in relation to such provisions of Division 4 as are specified in Part 2 of Schedule 3, a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, specified in that Part to be an associated person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: excludes, in relation to such provisions of Division 4 as are specified in Part 3 of Schedule 3, a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, specified in that Part not to be an associated person;

def.name: Controller
def.leadIn: controller (控制人), in relation to a corporation, means any person who is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a shareholder controller of the corporation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an indirect controller of the corporation;

subsection.def: default proceedings (違責處理程序) means any proceedings or other action taken by a recognized clearing house under its default rules;
default rules (違責處理規則), in relation to a recognized clearing house, means the rules of the clearing house required by section 40(2) or made under section 40(2A); (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 57)
defaulter (違責者) means a recognized clearing house, or a clearing participant, that is the subject of any default proceedings; (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 57)

def.name: IndirectController
def.leadIn: indirect controller (間接控制人), in relation to a corporation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), means a person in accordance with whose directions or instructions the directors of the corporation or of another corporation of which it is a subsidiary are accustomed or obliged to act;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: excludes, in relation to such provisions of Division 4 as are specified in Part 4 of Schedule 3, a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, specified in that Part not to be an indirect controller;

def.name: MarketCharge
def.leadIn: market charge (市場押記) means a charge, whether fixed or floating, granted in favour of a recognized clearing house—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: over any property which is held by or deposited with the clearing house; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of securing liabilities arising directly in connection with the clearing house’s ensuring the settlement of a market contract;

subsection.def: market collateral (市場抵押品) means any property which is held by or deposited with a recognized clearing house for the purpose of securing liabilities arising directly in connection with the clearing house’s ensuring the settlement of a market contract;
relevant corporation (相關法團) means a corporation of which a relevant recognized exchange controller is a controller;

def.name: RelevantOfficeholder
def.leadIn: relevant office-holder (有關人員) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Official Receiver;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person acting in relation to a company as its liquidator, receiver or manager;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person acting in relation to an individual as his trustee in bankruptcy or interim receiver of his property; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a person appointed pursuant to an order for the administration in bankruptcy of an insolvent estate of a deceased person;

subsection.def: relevant recognized exchange controller (相關認可控制人) means a recognized exchange controller which is a controller of the Stock Exchange Company;
settlement (交收), in relation to a market contract, includes partial settlement;

shareholder controller (股東控制人), in relation to a corporation, means any person who, either alone or with any associated person or persons, is entitled to exercise, or control the exercise of, more than 35% of the voting power at any general meeting of the corporation or of another corporation of which it is a subsidiary.

subsection.content: Where a charge is granted partly for the purpose specified in the definition of market charge in subsection (1) and partly for other purposes, the charge is in Division 3 a market charge in so far as it has effect for that specified purpose.

subsection.def: Where any collateral is granted partly for the purpose specified in the definition of market collateral in subsection (1) and partly for other purposes, the collateral is in Division 3 market collateral in so far as it has been provided for that specified purpose.

subsection.leadIn: In Division 3, a reference to the law of insolvency includes a reference to every provision made by or under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); and (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other enactment which is concerned with or in any way related to the insolvency of a person.

subsection.content: In Division 3, a reference to settlement in relation to a market contract is a reference to the discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to the contract, whether by performance, compromise or otherwise.

Where there is a reference in this or any other Ordinance to a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (however expressed), the term controller shall be construed in accordance with the provisions of this section.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.def: to avoid doubt, the reference to property held by or deposited with a recognized clearing house for the purpose described in the definition of market collateral in subsection (1) includes property held or deposited as collateral, margin or guarantee fund contributions (by whatever name called in the rules of the clearing house) and whether the property is held or deposited by way of charge, transfer or other arrangement; and

def.name: GuaranteeFundContribution
def.leadIn: guarantee fund contribution (保證基金供款) means any contribution by a recognized clearing house or its clearing participants to a fund that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: is maintained by the clearing house to cover losses, including losses arising in connection with—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: it being unable or likely to become unable to meet its obligations in respect of any unsettled or open market contract; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a clearing participant being unable, or appearing to be, or likely to become, unable to meet obligations in respect of unsettled or open market contracts to which that participant is a party; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: may be applied for that purpose under the default rules of the clearing house. (Added 6 of 2014 s. 57)

section.name: s19
section.heading: Recognition of exchange company

subsection.leadIn: No person shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: operate a stock market unless the person is—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the Stock Exchange Company;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a recognized exchange company of which a relevant recognized exchange controller is a controller; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a relevant recognized exchange controller which is itself a recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: operate a futures market unless the person is a recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: assist in the operation of a stock market which is operated in contravention of this subsection;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: assist in the operation of a futures market which is operated in contravention of this subsection.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: it may, after consultation with the public and then the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a company, recognize the company as an exchange company—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as it considers appropriate specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of conditions which may be specified in a notice under subsection (2), the Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange company, amend or revoke any condition specified in the first-mentioned notice or impose new conditions, where the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so on a ground specified in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has consulted the Financial Secretary.

subsection.content: Where the Commission amends or revokes any condition or imposes any new condition by a notice under subsection (3), the amendment, revocation or imposition takes effect at the time of service of the notice or at the time specified in the notice, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Where a company becomes a recognized exchange company, the Commission shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

Where a company is seeking to be a recognized exchange company and the Commission is minded not to recognize the company under subsection (2), the Commission shall give the company a reasonable opportunity of being heard before making a decision not to recognize the company.

Where the Commission refuses to recognize a company as an exchange company under subsection (2), the Commission shall, by notice in writing served on the company, inform the company of the refusal and of the reasons for it.

subsection.leadIn: A person shall not be regarded as contravening—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subsection (1)(b) by reason only of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: carrying on a business of providing automated trading services that constitutes an operation of a futures market if—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: that person is authorized to provide the services under section 95(2) or is an intermediary licensed or registered for Type 7 regulated activity; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: by virtue of the authorization, licence or registration, that person is permitted to engage in activities that constitute an operation of a futures market; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: carrying on a business of dealing in futures contracts that constitutes an operation of a futures market if—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: that person is an intermediary licensed or registered for Type 2 regulated activity; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: by virtue of the licence or registration, that person is permitted to engage in activities that constitute an operation of a futures market; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subsection (1)(d) by reason only of assisting in carrying on a business of providing automated trading services that constitutes an operation of a futures market or carrying on a business of dealing in futures contracts that constitutes an operation of a futures market if the conditions referred to in paragraph (a)(i)(A) and (B) or (ii)(A) and (B) (as the case may be) are fulfilled in relation to the business of providing automated trading services or the business of dealing in futures contracts.

subsection.def: In subsection (1), stock market (證券市場) shall have the meaning assigned to it in the definition of stock market in section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1, except that a reference to securities in that definition shall be construed as not including a reference to interests in any collective investment scheme.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Transactions that may be conducted on recognized stock market and recognized futures market

subsection.leadIn: No transaction may be conducted on a recognized stock market other than dealings in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: securities; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other financial products which are approved by the Commission by notice published in the Gazette, either generally or in a particular case.

subsection.leadIn: No transaction may be conducted on a recognized futures market other than dealings in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: futures contracts; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other financial products,

subsection.continued: which are approved by the Commission by notice published in the Gazette, either generally or in a particular case.

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (1) or (2) is not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Duties of recognized exchange company

subsection.leadIn: It shall be the duty of a recognized exchange company to ensure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: so far as reasonably practicable, an orderly, informed and fair market—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of a recognized exchange company which operates a stock market, in securities that are traded on that stock market or through the facilities of that company; (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 3)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a recognized exchange company which operates a futures market, in futures contracts that are traded on that futures market or through the facilities of that company; or (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 3)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in OTC derivative products that are traded through the facilities of the recognized exchange company; and (Added 6 of 2014 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that risks associated with its business and operations are managed prudently.

subsection.leadIn: In discharging its duty under subsection (1), a recognized exchange company shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: act in the interest of the public, having particular regard to the interest of the investing public; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that the interest of the public prevails where it conflicts with the interest of the recognized exchange company.

subsection.content: A recognized exchange company shall operate its facilities in accordance with the rules made under section 23 and approved under section 24.
A recognized exchange company shall formulate and implement appropriate procedures for ensuring that its exchange participants comply with the rules of the company.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange company shall immediately notify the Commission if it becomes aware—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that any of its exchange participants is unable to comply with any rules of the company or any financial resources rules; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of a financial irregularity or other matter which in the opinion of the company may indicate that the financial standing or integrity of an exchange participant is in question, or that an exchange participant may not be able to meet his legal obligations.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange company shall at all times provide and maintain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate and properly equipped premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: competent personnel; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: automated systems with adequate capacity, facilities to meet contingencies or emergencies, security arrangements and technical support,

subsection.continued: for the conduct of its business.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Immunity, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of section 380(1), no civil liability, whether arising in contract, tort, defamation, equity or otherwise, shall be incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a recognized exchange company; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting on behalf of a recognized exchange company, including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any member of the board of directors of the company; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any member of any committee established by the company,

subsection.continued: in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith in the discharge or purported discharge of the duties of the company under section 21 or in the performance or purported performance of its functions under its rules.

subsection.content: Where, in the discharge or purported discharge of its duties under section 63, a recognized exchange controller gives an instruction or direction or makes a request to a recognized exchange company of which it is a controller, the company’s duties under section 21 or under its rules are not applicable to the company in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith by the company in compliance with the instruction, direction or request.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Rules by recognized exchange company

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting any of its other powers to make rules, a recognized exchange company may make rules for such matters as are necessary or desirable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation and efficient operation of the market which it operates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of its exchange participants and holders of trading rights;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the establishment and maintenance of compensation arrangements for the investing public.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), a recognized exchange company which may operate a stock market may make rules for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: applications for the listing of securities and the requirements to be met before securities may be listed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the entering into of agreements between the recognized exchange company and other persons in connection with the listing of securities, and the enforcement of those agreements by the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the cancellation and withdrawal of the listing of, and the suspension and resumption of dealings in, securities listed on the recognized stock market operated by the recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the imposition on any person of obligations to observe specified standards of conduct or to perform, or refrain from performing, specified acts reasonably imposed in connection with the listing or continued listing of securities;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the admission of securities which are regulated in a jurisdiction outside Hong Kong to trading on a recognized stock market operated by the recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the penalties or sanctions which may be imposed by the recognized exchange company for a breach of rules made under this section;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: procedures or conditions which may be imposed, or circumstances which are required to exist, in relation to matters which are provided for in the rules made under this section;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: dealing with possible conflicts of interest that might arise where a relevant corporation or a relevant recognized exchange controller seeks to be or is a listed corporation;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: such other matters as are necessary or desirable for the proper and efficient operation and management of the recognized exchange company.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange company, request the company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make rules specified in the request within the period specified in that request; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to amend rules referred to in the request in the manner and within the period specified in that request.

subsection.content: Before making a request under subsection (3), the Commission shall consult the Financial Secretary and the recognized exchange company to which the request relates.

Where the Commission is satisfied that a recognized exchange company has not complied with a request referred to in subsection (3) within the period specified in the request, the Commission may make or amend the rules specified in the request instead of the company.

subsection.leadIn: The following persons or anyone who seeks to become any such person shall, if required to do so by the rules of a recognized exchange company, make a statutory declaration concerning such matters as may be specified in the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exchange participant or holder of trading rights of the company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a director of a corporation which uses the facilities of the company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a director of a corporation which is seeking to have any of its securities listed; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a director or adviser of a listed corporation.

subsection.content: In making rules under this section, a recognized exchange company shall take into account that a solicitor or certified public accountant acting in his professional capacity in private practice has duties imposed by law and under rules of professional conduct. (Amended 23 of 2004 s. 56)

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange company shall, in circumstances stipulated in arrangements agreed from time to time between it and The Law Society of Hong Kong or the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council, refer breaches of rules made under this section— (Amended 23 of 2004 s. 56; L.N. 66 of 2022)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which are alleged to have been committed by a solicitor or certified public accountant in private practice; and (Amended 23 of 2004 s. 56)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which may also constitute a breach of duty imposed by law or under rules of professional conduct,

subsection.continued: to The Law Society of Hong Kong or the Accounting and Financial Reporting Council (as the case may be), for determination of whether to make a finding, impose a penalty or sanction or take other disciplinary action. (Amended 23 of 2004 s. 56; L.N. 66 of 2022)

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsections (7) and (8), a person shall be regarded as acting in the capacity of a solicitor or certified public accountant in private practice if in the course of private practice he provides legal or professional accountancy services to a client, but shall not be regarded as so acting where, in respect of a matter governed by rules made under this section, he is also connected with the matter in any other capacity. (Amended 23 of 2004 s. 56)

section.name: s24
section.heading: Approval of rules or amendments to rules of recognized exchange company

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (7), no rule (whether or not made under section 23) of a recognized exchange company or any amendment thereto shall have effect unless it has the approval in writing of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange company shall submit or cause to be submitted to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for its approval the rules and every amendment thereto that require approval under subsection (1), together with explanations of their purpose and likely effect, including their effect on the investing public, in sufficient detail to enable the Commission to decide whether to approve them or refuse to approve them; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for its information the rules which belong to a class the subject of a declaration under subsection (7) and every amendment to the rules, as soon as reasonably practicable after they have been made.

subsection.content: The Commission shall, not later than 6 weeks after the receipt of a submission under subsection (2)(a) from a recognized exchange company, by notice in writing served on the company, give its approval or refuse to give its approval (together with its reasons for the refusal) to the rules or amendment of the rules (as the case may be) or any part thereof, the subject of the submission.
The Commission may give its approval under subsection (3) subject to requirements which shall be satisfied before the rules or amendment of the rules or any part thereof take effect.
The Commission may in a particular case, with the agreement of the recognized exchange company concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).
The Financial Secretary may, after consultation with the Commission and the recognized exchange company concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).

The Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette, declare any class of rules of a recognized exchange company to be a class of rules which are not required to be approved under subsection (1) and, accordingly, any rules of the company which belong to that class (including any amendment thereto) shall have effect notwithstanding that they have not been so approved.
Neither the rules under section 23 nor a notice under subsection (7) is subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Transfer and resumption of functions of Commission

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may request the Chief Executive in Council to transfer, by order (transfer order) published in the Gazette, to a recognized exchange company (designated exchange company)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a function to which this section applies; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that function in so far as it applies to the exchange participants or applicants to be exchange participants of the designated exchange company,

subsection.continued: if the Commission is satisfied that the designated exchange company is willing and able to perform the function.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a function of the Commission under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Part V;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 145; (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Parts II and XII of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); and (Replaced 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Part 5 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622). (Added 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.leadIn: A function to which this section applies may be transferred by a transfer order either in whole or in part, and the transfer may be subject to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reservation that the Commission is to perform the function concurrently with the designated exchange company; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other conditions as the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: A transfer order may contain such incidental, supplemental and consequential provisions as may be necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving full effect to the order.

The Commission shall not request that a transfer order be made in respect of the making of financial resources rules unless the proposed designated exchange company has first supplied the Commission with a draft of the financial resources rules which it proposes to make, and the Commission is satisfied that the rules, if made, will afford the investing public an adequate level of protection.

The Commission may at the request or with the consent of a designated exchange company resume a function transferred by a transfer order, but the resumption takes effect only by order of the Chief Executive in Council.

The Chief Executive in Council may order that the Commission resume a function transferred to a designated exchange company by a transfer order if the Commission so requests and if it appears to the Chief Executive in Council to be in the public interest to do so.

A transfer order may provide for a designated exchange company to retain all or any of the fees payable in relation to the performance of a transferred function, and an order made under subsection (6) or (7) may provide for the Commission to retain all or any such fees, from a date specified in the order.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Appointment of chief executive of recognized exchange company requires approval of Commission
section.content: No appointment of a person as chief executive of a recognized exchange company shall have effect unless the appointment has the approval in writing of the Commission.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Production of records, etc. by recognized exchange company

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange company, require the company to provide to the Commission, within such period as the Commission may specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such books and records kept by it in connection with or for the purposes of its business or in respect of any trading in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other information relating to its business or any trading in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products,

subsection.continued: as the Commission may reasonably require for the performance of its functions. (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 4)

subsection.content: A recognized exchange company served with a notice under subsection (1) which, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Withdrawal of recognition of exchange company and direction to cease to provide facilities or services

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (4), (5) and (6), the Commission may, after consultation with the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: withdraw the company’s recognition as an exchange company with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: direct the company to cease with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to provide or operate such facilities as are specified therein; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: to provide such services as are specified therein.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may by the notice served under subsection (1) permit the recognized exchange company to continue, on or after the date on which the withdrawal or direction is to take effect, to carry on such activities affected by the withdrawal or direction as the Commission may specify in the notice for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: closing down the operations of the company or ceasing to provide the services specified in the notice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: protecting the interest of the investing public or the public interest.

subsection.content: Where the Commission has granted a permission to a recognized exchange company under subsection (2), the company shall not, by reason of its carrying on the activities in accordance with the permission, be regarded as having contravened section 19(1).

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may only serve a notice under subsection (1) in relation to a recognized exchange company that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any requirement of this Ordinance or with a condition imposed under section 19;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is being wound up;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ceases to operate a market that it has been authorized to operate by virtue of section 19; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: requests the Commission to do so.

subsection.content: Except where responding to a request under subsection (4)(d), the Commission shall not exercise its power under subsection (1) in relation to a recognized exchange company unless it has given the company a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

Except where responding to a request under subsection (4)(d), the Commission shall give the recognized exchange company not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of its intention to serve a notice under subsection (1) and the grounds for doing so.
Where the Commission withdraws a company’s recognition as an exchange company under subsection (1)(a), it shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: A notice served under subsection (1)(a) shall not take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), until the expiration of the period within which an appeal against the notice may be made under section 33; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal against the notice is made under section 33, until the appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or determined.

subsection.content: A notice served under subsection (1)(b) shall take effect immediately.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Direction to cease to provide facilities or services in emergencies

subsection.content: In addition to the powers of the Commission under section 28, the Commission may, after consultation with a recognized exchange company, by notice in writing served on the company, direct the company to cease to provide or operate such facilities or cease to provide such services as are specified in the notice for a period not exceeding 5 business days.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may only serve a notice under subsection (1) if it is of the opinion that the orderly transaction of business on the stock market or futures market (as the case may be) is being, or is likely to be, impeded because—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an emergency or natural disaster has occurred in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there exists an economic or financial crisis, whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere, or any other circumstances, which is likely to prejudice orderly transaction of business on the stock market or futures market (as the case may be).

subsection.content: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on the recognized exchange company, extend the direction under subsection (1) for further periods not exceeding 10 business days in all.
A notice served under this section shall take effect immediately.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Contravention of notice constitutes offence
section.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provides or operates facilities; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provides services,

section.continued: in contravention of a notice under section 28(1)(b) or 29(1) or (3) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Prevention of entry into closed trading markets

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may take all necessary steps to ensure compliance with a notice under section 28(1)(b) or 29(1) or (3) and may, in particular, secure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the facilities to which the notice relates; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the premises on which such facilities are kept or the premises on which the services to which the notice relates are provided,

subsection.continued: against use for dealings in securities or futures contracts or other purposes.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 if, without the authority of the Commission or reasonable excuse, he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes use of any facilities or services to which the notice under section 28(1)(b) or 29(1) or (3) relates; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: enters the premises on which such facilities are kept or the premises on which such services are provided.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Publication of directions
section.leadIn: Where the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: directs a recognized exchange company under section 28(1)(b) or 29(1) to cease to provide or operate any facilities or cease to provide any services; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: extends under section 29(3) a direction referred to in that section,

section.continued: it shall cause notice of the particulars of the direction or extension (as the case may be) to be published in the Gazette.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Appeals

subsection.content: A company served with a notice under section 28(1) or 29(1) or (3) may appeal against the notice to the Chief Executive in Council not later than 14 days after the date of service of the notice or such longer period (if any) as the Commission specifies in the notice.
The decision of the Chief Executive in Council on an appeal under subsection (1) shall be final.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Restriction on use of titles relating to exchanges, markets, etc.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if he, without the authority of the Commission or reasonable excuse, takes or uses the title—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: “stock exchange”;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: “stock market”;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: “commodity exchange”;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: “futures exchange”;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: “futures market”;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: “unified exchange”;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: “united exchange”;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: “證券交易所”;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: “股票交易所”;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: “證券市場”;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: “股票市場”;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: “商品交易所”;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.content: “期貨交易所”;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: “期貨市場”;

paragraph.name: o
paragraph.content: “聯合交易所”,

subsection.continued: or anything which closely resembles any such title.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under this section is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Contract limits and reportable open position

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to section 398(7) and (8), the Commission may make rules to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe limits on, or conditions relating to, the number of futures contracts which may be held or controlled, directly or indirectly, by any person, whether or not such contracts are traded on a recognized futures market or through the facilities of a recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribe limits on, or conditions relating to, the number of options contracts which may be held or controlled, directly or indirectly, by any person, whether or not such contracts are traded on a recognized stock market or recognized futures market or through the facilities of a recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: require a person holding or controlling a reportable position to lodge a notice of that reportable position with a recognized exchange company or the Commission;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner in which and the period within which a notice of a reportable position is to be lodged;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prescribe the information by which a notice of a reportable position is to be accompanied.

subsection.content: The Commission shall consult the Financial Secretary before making rules under subsection (1)(e).

Subsection (1) does not prohibit the Commission from prescribing different limits or conditions, or different reportable positions, for different types or classes of futures or options contracts, or from exempting specified futures or options contracts.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of subsection (1) and without prejudice to section 398(7) and (8), the Commission may make rules for the purposes of this section to prohibit a person from—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly entering, during a specified period, into transactions of a specified class in excess of a specified amount; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: directly or indirectly holding or controlling positions of a specified class in excess of a specified position limit.

subsection.leadIn: Rules made under this section may provide that a person who, without reasonable excuse, contravenes any specified provision of the rules that applies to the person commits an offence and is liable to a specified penalty not exceeding—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment a fine at level 6 and a term of imprisonment of 2 years;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction a fine at level 3 and a term of imprisonment of 6 months.

subsection.def: In this section reportable position (須申報的持倉量) means an open position in futures or options contracts the number or total value of which is in excess of a number or total value specified by rules made under this section.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Rules by Commission

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to section 398(7) and (8), the Commission may make rules in respect of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the listing of securities, and in particular—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prescribing the requirements to be met before securities may be listed;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: prescribing the procedure for dealing with applications for the listing of securities;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: providing for the cancellation of the listing of any specified securities if the Commission’s requirements for listing, or the requirements of the undertaking referred to in paragraph (e), are not complied with or the Commission considers that such action is necessary to maintain an orderly market in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the conditions subject to which, and the circumstances in which, a recognized exchange company shall suspend dealings in securities or shall direct that dealings in securities recommence;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the procedure for and the method of allotment of any securities arising out of an offer made to members of the public in respect of those securities;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: persons who may be admitted as an exchange participant of a recognized exchange company;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: requiring corporations the securities of which are listed or accepted for listing to enter into an undertaking in the form prescribed in the rules with a recognized exchange company which may operate a stock market under section 19 to provide such information at such times as may be specified, and to carry out such duties in relation to its securities as may be imposed, in the undertaking; (Amended 16 of 2016 s. 3)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: requiring a recognized exchange company which has become aware of any matter which adversely affects, or is likely to adversely affect, the ability of any exchange participant of the company to meet its obligations as an exchange participant, to make a report concerning the matter to the Commission as soon as reasonably practicable after becoming aware of the matter;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: requiring a recognized exchange company when it expels any of its exchange participants, or suspends any of its exchange participants from trading on the recognized stock market or recognized futures market it operates or through its facilities, or requests any of its exchange participants to resign as an exchange participant, to notify the Commission of that fact within 3 business days after the expulsion, suspension or making of the request (as the case may be) and, in addition, to cause the expulsion, suspension or request to be notified to the public in such manner and within such period as may be prescribed in the rules;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: any matter which is to be or may be prescribed by rules made under section 23.

subsection.leadIn: Before making any rules in respect of any matter specified in subsection (1), the Commission shall consult—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Financial Secretary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the recognized exchange company or all the recognized exchange companies (as the case may be) to which that matter relates.

subsection.content: Nothing in this section prevents a recognized exchange company from making rules under section 23 on any matter referred to in subsection (1), but any such rules shall have effect only to the extent that they are not repugnant to any rule made by the Commission under subsection (1).

section.name: s37
section.heading: Recognition of clearing house

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: it may, after consultation with the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a company, recognize the company as a clearing house—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as it considers appropriate specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of conditions which may be specified in a notice under subsection (1), the Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized clearing house, amend or revoke any condition specified in the first-mentioned notice or impose new conditions, where the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so on a ground specified in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has consulted the Financial Secretary.

subsection.content: Where the Commission amends or revokes any condition or imposes any new condition by a notice under subsection (2), the amendment, revocation or imposition takes effect at the time of service of the notice or at the time specified in the notice, whichever is the later.
Where a company becomes a recognized clearing house, the Commission shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

Where a company is seeking to be a recognized clearing house and the Commission is minded not to recognize the company under subsection (1), the Commission shall give the company a reasonable opportunity of being heard before making a decision not to recognize the company.

Where the Commission refuses to recognize a company as a clearing house under subsection (1), the Commission shall, by notice in writing served on the company, inform the company of the refusal and of the reasons for it.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Duties of recognized clearing house

subsection.leadIn: It shall be the duty of a recognized clearing house to ensure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: so far as reasonably practicable, that there are orderly, fair and expeditious clearing and settlement arrangements for any transactions in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products cleared or settled through its facilities; and (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 5)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that risks associated with its business and operations are managed prudently.

subsection.leadIn: In discharging its duty under subsection (1), a recognized clearing house shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: act in the interest of the public, having particular regard to the interest of the investing public; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that the interest of the public prevails where it conflicts with the interest of the recognized clearing house.

subsection.content: A recognized clearing house shall operate its facilities in accordance with the rules made under section 40 and approved under section 41.
A recognized clearing house shall formulate and implement appropriate procedures for ensuring that its clearing participants comply with the rules of the clearing house.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house shall at all times provide and maintain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: adequate and properly equipped premises;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: competent personnel; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: automated systems with adequate capacity, facilities to meet contingencies or emergencies, security arrangements and technical support,

subsection.continued: for the conduct of its business.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Immunity, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of section 380(1), no civil liability, whether arising in contract, tort, defamation, equity or otherwise, shall be incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a recognized clearing house; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting on behalf of a recognized clearing house, including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any member of the board of directors of the clearing house; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any member of any committee established by the clearing house,

subsection.continued: in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith in the discharge or purported discharge of the duties of the clearing house under sections 38 and 47 or in the performance or purported performance of its functions under its rules, including its default rules.

subsection.content: Where, in the discharge or purported discharge of its duties under section 63, a recognized exchange controller gives an instruction or direction or makes a request to a recognized clearing house of which it is a controller, the clearing house’s duties under sections 38 and 47 or under its rules (including its default rules) are not applicable to the clearing house in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith by the clearing house in compliance with the instruction, direction or request.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of section 380(1), no civil liability, whether arising in contract, tort, defamation, equity or otherwise, shall be incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person performing, by virtue of a delegation under the default rules of a recognized clearing house, a function of the clearing house in connection with any default proceedings; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting on behalf of a person referred to in paragraph (a), including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any member of the board of directors of that person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any member of any committee established by that person,

subsection.continued: in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith in the performance and purported performance of that function.

subsection.content: Any failure by a recognized clearing house to comply with its rules in relation to a matter does not prevent the matter from being treated for the purposes of this Ordinance as done in accordance with the rules so long as the failure does not substantially affect the rights of a person entitled to require compliance with the rules.

Where a relevant office-holder takes action in relation to property of a defaulter which is liable to be dealt with in accordance with the default rules of a recognized clearing house, and believes on reasonable grounds that he is entitled to take that action, he is not liable to any person in respect of any loss or damage resulting from his action except in so far as the loss or damage (as the case may be) is caused by the office-holder’s own negligence.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Rules by recognized clearing houses

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting any of its other powers to make rules, a recognized clearing house may make rules for such matters as are necessary or desirable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation and efficient operation of the clearing or settlement facilities which it operates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of its clearing participants;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the establishment and maintenance of compensation arrangements for the investing public.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house shall make rules which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide for the taking of proceedings or other action if a clearing participant appears to be unable, or likely to become unable, to meet his obligations in respect of all unsettled or open market contracts to which he is a party; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: comply with Part 5 of Schedule 3.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house may make rules to provide for the following purposes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: taking proceedings or other action if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the clearing house is unable, or likely to become unable, to meet its obligations in respect of any unsettled or open market contract to which it is a party as those obligations fall due; and

subparagraph.name: ii
