subparagraph.content: it becomes necessary or desirable for the clearing house to cease to provide or operate any clearing and settlement facilities provided or operated by it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: taking proceedings or other action in relation to any contracts entered into between a clearing participant and its clients if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the clearing participant appears to be unable, or likely to become unable, to meet its obligations in respect of all unsettled or open market contracts to which it is a party; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: those contracts relate to such unsettled or open market contracts recorded in a client account;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: taking proceedings or other action in relation to any positions or collateral relating to a contract entered into between a clearing participant and its clients referred to in paragraph (b) if—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the clearing participant appears to be unable, or likely to become unable, to meet its obligations in respect of all unsettled or open market contracts to which it is a party; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: those positions or collateral relate to such unsettled or open market contracts recorded in a client account. (Added 6 of 2014 s. 58)

subsection.content: Where a recognized clearing house takes default proceedings, all subsequent proceedings or other action taken under its rules for the settlement of market contracts to which the defaulter is a party shall be treated as taken under the default rules.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized clearing house, request the clearing house—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to make rules specified in the request within the period specified in that request; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to amend rules referred to in the request in the manner and within the period specified in that request.

subsection.content: Before making a request under subsection (4), the Commission shall consult the Financial Secretary and the recognized clearing house to which the request relates.

Where the Commission is satisfied that a recognized clearing house has not complied with a request referred to in subsection (4) within the period specified in the request, the Commission may make or amend the rules specified in the request instead of the recognized clearing house.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: client account (客户帳户), in relation to a clearing participant, means an account held with a recognized clearing house in the name of the clearing participant, other than a house account in which positions or collateral are recorded;

def.name: HouseAccount
def.leadIn: house account (結算所帳户), in relation to a clearing participant, means an account—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which is held with a recognized clearing house in the name of the clearing participant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in which the following are recorded—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the clearing participant’s own positions or collateral;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the positions or collateral of other persons that are regarded by the rules of the recognized clearing house to be the clearing participant’s own positions or collateral. (Added 6 of 2014 s. 58)

section.name: s41
section.heading: Approval of rules or amendments to rules of recognized clearing house

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (7), no rule (whether or not made under section 40) of a recognized clearing house or any amendment thereto shall have effect unless it has the approval in writing of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house shall submit or cause to be submitted to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for its approval the rules and every amendment thereto that require approval under subsection (1), together with explanations of their purpose and likely effect, including their effect on the investing public, in sufficient detail to enable the Commission to decide whether to approve them or refuse to approve them; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for its information the rules which belong to a class the subject of a declaration under subsection (7) and every amendment to the rules, as soon as reasonably practicable after they have been made.

subsection.content: The Commission shall, not later than 6 weeks after the receipt of a submission under subsection (2)(a) from a recognized clearing house, by notice in writing served on the clearing house, give its approval or refuse to give its approval (together with its reasons for the refusal) to the rules or amendment of the rules (as the case may be) or any part thereof, the subject of the submission.
The Commission may give its approval under subsection (3) subject to requirements which shall be satisfied before the rules or amendment of the rules or any part thereof take effect.
The Commission may in a particular case, with the agreement of the recognized clearing house concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).
The Financial Secretary may, after consultation with the Commission and the recognized clearing house concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).

The Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette, declare any class of rules of a recognized clearing house (except any default rules of the clearing house) to be a class of rules which are not required to be approved under subsection (1) and, accordingly, any rules of the clearing house which belong to that class (including any amendment thereto) shall have effect notwithstanding that they have not been so approved.
Neither the rules under section 40 nor a notice under subsection (7) is subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Production of records, etc. by recognized clearing house

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized clearing house, require the clearing house to provide to the Commission, within such period as the Commission may specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: such books and records kept by it in connection with or for the purposes of its business or in respect of any clearing and settlement arrangements for any transactions in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other information relating to its business or any clearing and settlement arrangements for any transactions in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products,

subsection.continued: as the Commission may reasonably require for the performance of its functions. (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 6)

subsection.content: A recognized clearing house served with a notice under subsection (1) which, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Withdrawal of recognition of clearing house and direction to cease to provide facilities

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (3), (4) and (5), the Commission may, after consultation with the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a recognized clearing house—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: withdraw the company’s recognition as a clearing house with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: direct the clearing house to cease to provide or operate with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose such clearing or settlement facilities as are specified therein.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may by the notice served under subsection (1) permit the recognized clearing house to continue, on or after the date on which the withdrawal or direction is to take effect, to carry on such activities affected by the withdrawal or direction as the Commission may specify in the notice for the purpose of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: closing down the operations of the clearing house; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: protecting the interest of the investing public or the public interest.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may only serve a notice under subsection (1) in relation to a recognized clearing house that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: fails to comply with any requirement of this Ordinance or with a condition imposed under section 37;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is being wound up;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ceases to operate as a clearing house; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: requests the Commission to do so.

subsection.content: Except where responding to a request under subsection (3)(d), the Commission shall not exercise its power under subsection (1) in relation to a recognized clearing house unless it has given the clearing house a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

Except where responding to a request under subsection (3)(d), the Commission shall give the recognized clearing house not less than 14 days’ notice in writing of its intention to serve a notice under subsection (1) and the grounds for doing so.
Where the Commission withdraws a company’s recognition as a clearing house under subsection (1)(a), it shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

Where the Commission directs under subsection (1)(b) a recognized clearing house to cease to provide or operate any clearing or settlement facilities, it shall cause notice of the particulars of the direction to be published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: A notice served under subsection (1)(a) shall not take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), until the expiration of the period within which an appeal against the notice may be made under section 44; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal against the notice is made under section 44, until the appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or determined.

subsection.content: A notice served under subsection (1)(b) shall take effect immediately.

section.name: s44
section.heading: Appeals

subsection.content: A company served with a notice under section 43(1) may appeal against the notice to the Chief Executive in Council not later than 14 days after the date of service of the notice or such longer period (if any) as the Commission specifies in the notice.
The decision of the Chief Executive in Council on an appeal under subsection (1) shall be final.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Proceedings of recognized clearing house take precedence over law of insolvency

subsection.leadIn: None of the following shall be regarded as to any extent invalid at law on the ground of inconsistency with the law relating to distribution of the assets of a person on insolvency, bankruptcy or winding up, or on the appointment of a receiver over any of the assets of a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a market contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the rules of a recognized clearing house relating to the settlement of a market contract;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any proceedings or other action taken under the rules of a recognized clearing house relating to the settlement of a market contract;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a market charge;

paragraph.name: da
paragraph.leadIn: the provision of market collateral; (Added 6 of 2014 s. 59)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the default rules of a recognized clearing house; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: any default proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: The powers of a relevant office-holder in his capacity as such, and the powers of a court acting under the law of insolvency, shall not be exercised in such a way as to prevent or interfere with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the settlement in accordance with the rules of a recognized clearing house of a market contract; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any default proceedings.

subsection.content: Subsection (2) shall not operate to prevent a relevant office-holder from recovering an amount under section 51 after the completion of a matter referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Supplementary provisions as to default proceedings

subsection.content: A court may, on an application by a relevant office-holder, make such order as it considers appropriate altering or releasing him from compliance with the functions of his office that are affected by the fact that default proceedings are pending or could be taken, or have been or could have been taken.
The functions of the relevant office-holder referred to in subsection (1) shall be construed subject to an order made under that subsection.

Section 12, 14 or 20 to 20K of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6), sections 181, 183, 186 and 254 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) and sections 670 and 673 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) do not prevent or interfere with any default proceedings. (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s47
section.heading: Duty to report on completion of default proceedings

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house shall, upon the completion by it of any default proceedings, make a report on such proceedings stating in respect of each defaulter—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any net sum certified by the clearing house to be payable by or to the defaulter; or (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 60)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fact that no sum is so payable,

subsection.continued: (as the case may be) and the clearing house may include in that report such other particulars in respect of such proceedings as it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized clearing house which has made a report pursuant to subsection (1) shall supply the report to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Commission; and

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: any relevant office-holder acting in relation to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the defaulter to whom the report relates; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: that defaulter’s estate; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if there is no relevant office-holder referred to in subparagraph (i), the defaulter to whom the report relates.

subsection.content: Where the Commission receives pursuant to subsection (2) a report made pursuant to subsection (1), it may publish notice of that fact in such manner as it considers appropriate to bring it to the attention of creditors of the defaulter to whom the report relates.

subsection.leadIn: Where a relevant office-holder or defaulter receives pursuant to subsection (2) a report made pursuant to subsection (1), he shall, at the request of a creditor of the defaulter to whom the report relates—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make the report available for inspection by the creditor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on payment of such reasonable fee as the relevant office-holder or defaulter (as the case may be) determines, supply to the creditor all or any part of that report.

subsection.def: In subsections (2), (3) and (4), report (報告) includes a copy of a report.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Net sum payable on completion of default proceedings

subsection.content: This section applies with respect to any net sum referred to in section 47(1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: Where a bankruptcy or winding-up order has been made, or a resolution for voluntary winding up has been passed, any net sum shall, notwithstanding any provision of section 34 or 35 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) or section 264 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32), be— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provable in the bankruptcy or winding up or (as the case may be) payable to the relevant office-holder; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: taken into account, where appropriate, under section 35 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) or that section as applied in the case of a winding-up order under the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32). (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s49
section.heading: Disclaimer of property, rescission of contracts, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Section 59 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) and section 268 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) do not apply in relation to— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a market contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a contract effected by a recognized clearing house for the purpose of realizing property provided as market collateral;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a market charge; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any default proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: Section 42 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) and section 182 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) do not apply in relation to any act, matter or thing which has been done pursuant to— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a market contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a disposal of property pursuant to a market contract;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the provision of market collateral;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a contract effected by a recognized clearing house for the purpose of realizing property provided as market collateral, or any disposal of property pursuant to such a contract;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a disposal of property in accordance with the rules of a recognized clearing house as to the application of property provided as market collateral;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a disposal of property as a result of which the property becomes subject to a market charge, or any transaction pursuant to which that disposal is made;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: a disposal of property made in enforcing a market charge;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a market charge; or

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: any default proceedings.

section.name: s50
section.heading: Adjustment of prior transactions

subsection.leadIn: No order shall be made pursuant to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 49 or 50 of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 265D or 266 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); or (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920; 14 of 2016 s. 184)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: section 60 of the Conveyancing and Property Ordinance (Cap. 219),

subsection.continued: in relation to any matter to which this section applies.

subsection.leadIn: The matters to which this section applies are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a market contract;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a disposal of property pursuant to a market contract;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the provision of market collateral;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a contract effected by a recognized clearing house for the purpose of realizing property provided as market collateral;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a disposal of property in accordance with the rules of a recognized clearing house as to the application of property provided as market collateral;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a market charge; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: any default proceedings.

subsection.content: In subsection (1)(b), the reference to section 266 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32) includes that section as in force immediately before the commencement date of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (14 of 2016). (Added 14 of 2016 s. 184)

section.name: s51
section.heading: Right of relevant office-holder to recover certain amounts arising from certain transactions

subsection.leadIn: Where a clearing participant (the first participant) enters into a transaction for the sale or purchase of securities with another clearing participant (the second participant) at an undervalue or an over-value in circumstances described in subsection (2), and thereafter a relevant office-holder is acting in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the second participant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person who was, in respect of the transaction, the principal of the second participant (the second principal); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the estate of the second participant or the second principal,

subsection.continued: then, unless a court otherwise orders, the relevant office-holder may recover, from the first participant, or the person who was, in respect of the transaction, the principal of the first participant (the first principal), an amount equal to the prescribed gain obtained under the transaction by the first participant or the first principal (as the case may be). The amount is recoverable even if the transaction may have been discharged in accordance with the rules of a recognized clearing house and replaced by a market contract.

subsection.leadIn: The circumstances referred to in subsection (1) in which a transaction is entered into occur when—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prescribed event has occurred in relation to the second participant or the second principal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the first participant or the first principal knew or ought reasonably to have known—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of the first participant, that a prescribed event was likely to occur in relation to the second participant or the second principal;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of the first principal, that a prescribed event was likely to occur in relation to the second principal,

paragraph.continued: and the event occurs within the period of 6 months immediately following the date on which the transaction was so entered into.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: PrescribedEvent
def.leadIn: prescribed event (訂明事件), in relation to a second participant or a second principal, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: grounds exist for a creditor to present a bankruptcy petition against the second participant or the second principal (as the case may be);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the making of a statement in the specified form in respect of the second participant or the second principal (as the case may be) pursuant to section 228A of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); (Amended 28 of 2003 s. 129; 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920; 14 of 2016 s. 185)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a meeting of creditors summoned in relation to the second participant or the second principal (as the case may be) pursuant to section 241 of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); or (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the presentation of a petition for the winding up of the second participant or the second principal (as the case may be) by a court;

def.name: PrescribedGain
def.leadIn: prescribed gain (訂明收益), in relation to a transaction referred to in subsection (1), means the difference between—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the market value of the securities the subject of the transaction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the value of the consideration for the transaction,

def.continued: as at the time the transaction was entered into.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Application of market collateral not affected by certain other interests, etc.

subsection.content: The provisions of this section have effect with respect to the application by a recognized clearing house of property provided as market collateral.

So far as necessary to enable the property to be applied in accordance with the rules of a recognized clearing house, it may be so applied notwithstanding any prior equitable interest or right, or any right or remedy arising from a breach of fiduciary duty, unless the clearing house had actual notice of the interest, right or breach of duty (as the case may be) at the time the property was provided as market collateral.

No right or remedy arising subsequently to the property being provided as market collateral may be enforced so as to prevent or interfere with the application of the property by the recognized clearing house in accordance with its rules.

Where a recognized clearing house has power by virtue of the provisions of this section to apply property notwithstanding an interest, right or remedy, a person to whom the clearing house disposes of the property in accordance with its rules takes free from that interest, right or remedy.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Enforcement of judgments over property subject to market charge, etc.

subsection.content: Where property is subject to a market charge or has been provided as market collateral, no execution or other legal process for the enforcement of a judgment or order may be commenced or continued, and no distress may be levied, against the property by a person not seeking to enforce any interest in or security over the property, except with the consent of the recognized clearing house concerned.

Where by virtue of this section a person would not be entitled to enforce a judgment or order against any property, any injunction or other remedy granted with a view to facilitating the enforcement of any such judgment or order shall not extend to that property.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Law of insolvency in other jurisdictions

subsection.leadIn: A court shall not, pursuant to any enactment or rule of law, recognize or give effect to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order of a court exercising jurisdiction under the law of insolvency in a place outside Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an act of a person appointed in that place to perform a function under the law of insolvency there,

subsection.continued: in so far as making the order or doing the act would be prohibited in the case of a court in Hong Kong or a relevant office-holder by provisions made by or under this Ordinance.

subsection.def: In this section, law of insolvency (破產清盤法), in relation to a place outside Hong Kong, means any law of that place which is similar to, or serves the same purposes as, any part of the law of insolvency in Hong Kong.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Clearing participant to be party to certain transactions as principal

subsection.leadIn: Where a clearing participant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in his capacity as such enters into any transaction (including a market contract) with a recognized clearing house; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: but for this subsection, would be a party to that transaction as agent,

subsection.continued: then, notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law, as between, but only as between, the clearing house and any other person (including the clearing participant and the person who is his principal in respect of that transaction), the clearing participant shall for all purposes (including any action, claim or demand, either civil or criminal)—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: be deemed not to be a party to that transaction as agent; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: be deemed to be a party to that transaction as principal.

subsection.leadIn: Where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 2 or more clearing participants in their capacities as such enter into any transaction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: but for this subsection, any such clearing participant would be a party to that transaction as agent,

subsection.continued: then, notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law, any such clearing participant to whom paragraph (b) applies shall for all purposes (including any action, claim or demand, either civil or criminal), except as between, but only as between, him and the person who is his principal in respect of that transaction—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: be deemed not to be a party to that transaction as agent; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: be deemed to be a party to that transaction as principal.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Property deposited with recognized clearing house

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), where any property is deposited as market collateral by a clearing participant with a recognized clearing house in accordance with the rules of the clearing house, then, notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law, no action, claim or demand, either civil or criminal, in respect of any right, title or interest in such property held or enjoyed by any person lies, or shall be commenced or allowed, against the clearing house or its nominees.

The operation of subsection (1) in respect of any property deposited as market collateral with a recognized clearing house is subject to the modifications and exclusions provided in the rules of the clearing house.

subsection.leadIn: This section does not operate to prejudice the operation of— (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920; 16 of 2016 s. 4)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 633 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any provision of the OFC rules relating to the rectification of the register of shareholders of an open-ended fund company. (Amended 16 of 2016 s. 4)

section.name: s57
section.heading: Preservation of rights, etc.
section.leadIn: Except to the extent that they expressly provide, the provisions of this Division do not operate to limit, restrict or otherwise affect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any right, title, interest, privilege, obligation or liability of a person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any investigation, legal proceeding or remedy in respect of any such right, title, interest, privilege, obligation or liability.

section.name: s58
section.heading: Amendment of Schedule 3

subsection.content: The Financial Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend Part 5 of Schedule 3.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that the power of the Financial Secretary under subsection (1) to amend Part 5 of Schedule 3 may be exercised in such a way as to include in that Part a provision which requires a recognized clearing house to have, as part of its default rules, rules which prohibit the clearing house from taking any proceedings or other action specified in the provision, either generally or in a particular case.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Recognition of exchange controller

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (20) and section 62, no person shall become or continue to be a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house unless the person is a recognized exchange controller.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: it may, with the consent in writing of the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a company, recognize the company as an exchange controller—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as it considers appropriate specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of conditions which may be specified in a notice under subsection (2), the Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange controller, amend or revoke any condition specified in the first-mentioned notice or impose new conditions, where the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so on a ground specified in paragraph (a) or (b) of that subsection; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has the consent in writing of the Financial Secretary to do so.

subsection.content: Where the Commission amends or revokes any condition or imposes any new condition by a notice under subsection (3), the amendment, revocation or imposition takes effect at the time of service of the notice or at the time specified in the notice, whichever is the later.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), a person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: Where a person is charged with an offence under subsection (5), it is a defence to the charge for the person to prove that the person did not know that the acts or circumstances by virtue of which the person became a controller of the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned were such as to have that effect.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house in contravention of subsection (1) (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (5) in relation to the contravention);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reason to suspect the existence of any of the acts or circumstances by virtue of which the person became the controller of the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subsequently becomes aware of the fact that the person has become such a controller,

subsection.continued: the person shall serve on the Commission, not later than 14 days after becoming aware of that fact, a notice in writing stating that the person has become such a controller.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, upon the service of a notice under subsection (7)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: recognize the person as an exchange controller in accordance with subsection (2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to recognize the person as an exchange controller.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house in contravention of subsection (1) (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (5) in relation to the contravention)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: declare that any votes cast at any meeting of the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) by the person after the person became the controller shall be void and of no effect; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: give such directions as it considers appropriate for any such meetings to be reconvened for voting anew on the business on which such votes were cast;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person or any of his associated persons shall not exercise any rights conferred on the person as a holder of securities in the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house, or any rights in securities in any such company which are otherwise controlled by the person, except for the purpose of ceasing to be such controller; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the Commission may, by notice in writing served on the person, direct the person to take such steps as are specified in the notice—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the purpose of causing the person to cease to be such controller; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: within such period as is specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.content: Without limiting the generality of steps referred to in subsection (9)(c) which may be specified in a notice under that subsection to be served on a person referred to in that subsection, such steps may consist in whole or in part of steps proposed in writing to the Commission by that person.

The steps specified in a notice under subsection (9)(c) may be framed so as to afford the person on whom the notice is served a choice between different ways of ceasing to be a controller of the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A notice served under subsection (9)(c) shall not take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), until the expiration of the period within which an appeal against the notice may be made under section 73; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal against the notice is made under section 73, until the appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or determined.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (14), a person served with a notice under subsection (9)(c) who fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (13) to prove that the person exercised reasonable diligence to comply with the notice concerned under subsection (9)(c) served on the person.

Where a person served with a notice under subsection (9)(c) fails to comply with the notice (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (13) in relation to the failure), the provisions of Part 6 of Schedule 3 shall immediately apply.

The provisions of this section, except subsection (5), shall apply to a person who became a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house before the commencement of this section as they apply to a person who became a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house on or after that commencement.
Where a company becomes a recognized exchange controller, the Commission shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

Where a company is seeking to be a recognized exchange controller and the Commission is minded not to recognize the company under subsection (2), the Commission shall give the company a reasonable opportunity of being heard before making a decision not to recognize the company.

Where the Commission refuses to recognize a company or a person as an exchange controller under subsection (2) or (8)(b), the Commission shall, by notice in writing served on the company or the person (as the case may be), inform the company or the person of the refusal and of the reasons for it.

Subsection (1) shall not apply to a person who is a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house if the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house is itself a recognized exchange controller.
A notice under subsection (9)(a) is not subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Interest of recognized exchange controller in recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house cannot be increased or decreased except with approval of Commission
section.leadIn: Where a recognized exchange controller is a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house, then, by virtue of this section and notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any interest the recognized exchange controller has in the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) as such controller cannot be increased or decreased except with the approval in writing of the Commission;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any attempt (whether in the form of an agreement or otherwise and by whomsoever) to increase or decrease any such interest in contravention of paragraph (a) is void for all purposes.

section.name: s61
section.heading: Person not to become minority controller of exchange controller, etc. without approval of Commission

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (2) and (16), on or after the commencement of this section, a person shall not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be or become a minority controller of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house except with the approval in writing of the Commission after consultation with the Financial Secretary; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if such approval is given, and subject to any condition specified in the approval disapplying this paragraph in whole or in part, increase the interest the person has as such minority controller except with the further approval in writing of the Commission after consultation with the Financial Secretary.

subsection.content: The Commission shall not give an approval under subsection (1)(a) or (b) unless it is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest.
Where the Commission refuses to give an approval under subsection (1)(a) or (b), it shall give notice in writing of its reasons for the refusal to the person concerned.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), a person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is charged with an offence under subsection (4), it is a defence to the charge for the person to prove that the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: did not know that the acts or circumstances by virtue of which the person became a minority controller, or increased the interest the person has as a minority controller (as the case may be) of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned were such as to have that effect; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: exercised reasonable diligence to avoid contravening subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: Where a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is a minority controller of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house in contravention of subsection (1) (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (4) in relation to the contravention);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: did not know and had no reason to suspect the existence of any of the acts or circumstances by virtue of which the person became the minority controller of that recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: subsequently becomes aware of the fact that the person has become such a minority controller,

subsection.continued: the person shall serve on the Commission, not later than 14 days after becoming aware of that fact, a notice in writing stating that the person has become such a minority controller.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, upon the service of a notice under subsection (6)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: approve the person as a minority controller in accordance with subsection (1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: refuse to approve the person as a minority controller.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is a minority controller of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house in contravention of subsection (1) (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (4) in relation to the contravention), the Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: declare that any votes cast at any meeting of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) by the person after the person became the minority controller, shall be void and of no effect; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: give such directions as it considers appropriate for any such meetings to be reconvened for voting anew on the business on which such votes were cast.

subsection.leadIn: Where a person is a minority controller of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house in contravention of subsection (1) or has failed to comply with a condition specified in an approval under that subsection (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (4) in relation to the contravention)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person or any of his associated persons shall not exercise any rights conferred on the person as a holder of securities in the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned or any rights in securities in any such company which are otherwise controlled by the person, except for the purpose of ceasing to be such controller; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the Commission may, by notice in writing served on the person, direct the person to take such steps as are specified in the notice—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: for the purpose of causing the person to cease to be a minority controller of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house the subject of that contravention or failure; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: within such period as is specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.content: Without limiting the generality of steps referred to in subsection (9)(b) which may be specified in a notice under that subsection to be served on a person referred to in that subsection, such steps may consist in whole or in part of steps proposed in writing to the Commission by that person.

The steps specified in a notice under subsection (9)(b) may be framed so as to afford the person on whom the notice is served a choice between different ways of ceasing to be a minority controller of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned.

subsection.leadIn: A notice served under subsection (9)(b) shall not take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), until the expiration of the period within which an appeal against the notice may be made under section 73; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal against the notice is made under section 73, until the appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or determined.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (14), a person served with a notice under subsection (9)(b) who fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (13) to prove that the person exercised reasonable diligence to comply with the notice concerned under subsection (9)(b) served on the person.

Where a person served with a notice under subsection (9)(b) fails to comply with the notice (and whether or not the person is charged with an offence under subsection (13) in relation to the failure), the provisions of Part 6 of Schedule 3 shall immediately apply.

The Commission may, after consultation with the Financial Secretary, make rules to exempt a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, specified in the rules from one or more of the requirements of subsection (1) subject to such conditions (if any) as are specified in the rules.

Where a person is seeking to be a minority controller of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house and the Commission is minded not to give approval under subsection (1) in relation thereto, the Commission shall give the person a reasonable opportunity of being heard before making a decision not to give such approval.

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in this section shall operate to prevent the Commission from approving under this or any other Ordinance the provisions of the constitution, or the provisions of an amendment to the constitution, of a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house which impose requirements additional to this section in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: interests held in the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) including, but not limited to, the exercise, or the control of the exercise, of voting power at any general meeting of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: steps to be taken for the purpose of causing a person to dispose of any such interest including, but not limited to, ceasing to be a minority controller (by whatever name called) of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be).

subsection.content: A notice under subsection (8) is not subsidiary legislation.

def.name: MinorityController
def.leadIn: In this section, minority controller (次要控制人), in relation to a recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), means any person who, either alone or with any associated person or persons, is entitled to exercise, or control the exercise of, 5% or more of the voting power at any general meeting of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) or of a corporation of which the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) is a subsidiary;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: does not include—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a recognized exchange controller; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a person, or a person belonging to a class of persons, specified in Part 7 of Schedule 3 not to be a minority controller for the purposes of this Division.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Exemption from section 59(1) and revocation of exemption

subsection.leadIn: Where the Financial Secretary is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: he may, by notice in writing served on a person, exempt the person from section 59(1)—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as he considers appropriate specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Financial Secretary is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: he may, by notice in writing served on a person the subject of an exemption under subsection (1) stating the reasons in support of the ground or grounds for the notice, revoke the exemption—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: subject to such conditions as he considers appropriate specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose, being a date reasonable in all the circumstances of the case.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), a person who fails to comply with a condition specified in a notice under subsection (1) or (2) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (3) to prove that the person exercised reasonable diligence to comply with the notice concerned under subsection (1) or (2) served on the person.
Without limiting the generality of the Financial Secretary’s power under subsection (1), a person is exempt from section 59(1) in the cases specified in Part 8 of Schedule 3.

For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that the Financial Secretary’s power under subsection (2) to revoke an exemption under subsection (1) includes the power to revoke and replace the exemption.

section.name: s63
section.heading: Duties of recognized exchange controller

subsection.leadIn: It shall be the duty of a recognized exchange controller which is a controller of a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house to ensure so far as reasonably practicable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an orderly, informed and fair market in securities or futures contracts traded on the stock market or futures market operated by the recognized exchange company or through the facilities of the company;

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: an orderly, informed and fair market in OTC derivative products traded through the facilities of the recognized exchange company; (Added 6 of 2014 s. 7)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are orderly, fair and expeditious clearing and settlement arrangements for any transactions in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products cleared or settled through the facilities of the recognized clearing house; (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 7)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that risks associated with its business and operations are managed prudently;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: that the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) complies with any lawful requirement placed on it under any enactment or rule of law and with any other legal requirement placed on it.

subsection.leadIn: In discharging its duty under subsection (1)(a), (b) or (c), a recognized exchange controller shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: act in the interest of the public, having particular regard to the interest of the investing public; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that the interest of the public prevails where it conflicts with the interest of the recognized exchange controller.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Immunity, etc.
section.leadIn: Without limiting the generality of section 380(1), no civil liability, whether arising in contract, tort, defamation, equity or otherwise, shall be incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a recognized exchange controller; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: any person acting on behalf of a recognized exchange controller, including—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any member of the board of directors of the recognized exchange controller; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any member of any committee established by the recognized exchange controller,

section.continued: in respect of anything done or omitted to be done in good faith in the discharge or purported discharge of the duties of the controller under section 63 or in the performance or purported performance of its functions under its rules.

section.name: s65
section.heading: Establishment and functions of Risk Management Committee

subsection.content: A recognized exchange controller shall establish and keep established a committee, to be called the Risk Management Committee, to formulate policies on risk management matters relating to the activities of the recognized exchange controller and of any recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house of which the recognized exchange controller is a controller and to submit such policies to the recognized exchange controller for its consideration.

subsection.leadIn: The Risk Management Committee shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the chairman of the recognized exchange controller who shall also be the chairman of the Committee; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not less than 4 or more than 7 other members.

subsection.content: The Financial Secretary shall appoint not less than 3 or more than 5 of the members referred to in subsection (2)(b).

subsection.leadIn: The recognized exchange controller shall appoint not more than 2 of the members referred to in subsection (2)(b) of whom not less than one shall be a member of the board of directors of the recognized exchange controller who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is such a member otherwise than by virtue of an appointment under section 77(1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is not the chief executive of the recognized exchange controller.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Rules by recognized exchange controllers

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting any of its other powers to make rules, a recognized exchange controller may make rules for such matters as are necessary or desirable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the discharge of its duties under section 63;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the establishment and maintenance of compensation arrangements for the investing public.

subsection.content: The Commission may, after consultation with the Financial Secretary, by notice published in the Gazette, declare a person or body of persons specified in the notice to be a person or body of persons (as the case may be) to which paragraph (c)(ii)(C) of the definition of rules in section 1 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 shall apply.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Approval of rules or amendments to rules of recognized exchange controller

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (7), no rule (whether or not made under section 66) of a recognized exchange controller or any amendment thereto shall have effect unless it has the approval in writing of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange controller shall submit or cause to be submitted to the Commission—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for its approval the rules and every amendment thereto that require approval under subsection (1), together with explanations of their purpose and likely effect, including their effect on the investing public, in sufficient detail to enable the Commission to decide whether to approve them or refuse to approve them; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for its information the rules which belong to a class the subject of a declaration under subsection (7) and every amendment to the rules, as soon as reasonably practicable after they have been made.

subsection.content: The Commission shall, not later than 6 weeks after the receipt of a submission under subsection (2)(a) from a recognized exchange controller, by notice in writing served on the controller, give its approval or refuse to give its approval (together with its reasons for the refusal) to the rules or amendment of the rules (as the case may be) or any part thereof, the subject of the submission.
The Commission may give its approval under subsection (3) subject to requirements which shall be satisfied before the rules or amendment of the rules or any part thereof take effect.
The Commission may in a particular case, with the agreement of the recognized exchange controller concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).
The Financial Secretary may, after consultation with the Commission and the recognized exchange controller concerned, extend the time prescribed in subsection (3).

The Commission may, by notice published in the Gazette, declare any class of rules of a recognized exchange controller to be a class of rules which are not required to be approved under subsection (1) and, accordingly, any rules of the controller which belong to that class (including any amendment thereto) shall have effect notwithstanding that they have not been so approved.
Neither the rules under section 66(1) nor a notice under subsection (7) is subsidiary legislation.

section.name: s68
section.heading: Transfer and resumption of functions of Commission

subsection.content: The Commission may request the Chief Executive in Council to transfer, by order (transfer order) published in the Gazette, to a recognized exchange controller (designated exchange controller), a function to which this section applies, if the Commission is satisfied that the designated exchange controller is willing and able to perform the function.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a function of the Commission under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: Part V;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 145;(Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: Parts II and XII of the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32); and (Replaced 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: Part 5 of the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622). (Added 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

subsection.leadIn: A function to which this section applies may be transferred by a transfer order either in whole or in part, and the transfer may be subject to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reservation that the Commission is to perform the function concurrently with the designated exchange controller; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other conditions as the Commission considers appropriate.

subsection.content: A transfer order may contain such incidental, supplemental and consequential provisions as may be necessary or expedient for the purpose of giving full effect to the order.

The Commission shall not request that a transfer order be made in respect of the making of financial resources rules unless the proposed designated exchange controller has first supplied the Commission with a draft of the financial resources rules which it proposes to make, and the Commission is satisfied that the rules, if made, will afford the investing public an adequate level of protection.

The Commission may at the request or with the consent of a designated exchange controller resume a function transferred by a transfer order, but the resumption takes effect only by order of the Chief Executive in Council.

The Chief Executive in Council may order that the Commission resume a function transferred to a designated exchange controller by a transfer order if the Commission so requests and if it appears to the Chief Executive in Council to be in the public interest to do so.

A transfer order may provide for a designated exchange controller to retain all or any of the fees payable in relation to the performance of a transferred function, and an order made under subsection (6) or (7) may provide for the Commission to retain all or any such fees, from a date specified in the order.

section.name: s69
section.heading: Chairman of recognized exchange controller

subsection.content: No person shall be the chairman of a company which is a recognized exchange controller unless he has the approval in writing of the Chief Executive to hold that office.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Chief Executive is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: he may, by notice in writing served on a person who is the chairman of a recognized exchange controller, remove the person from that office with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

section.name: s70
section.heading: Appointment of chief executive or chief operating officer of recognized exchange controller requires approval of Commission

subsection.content: No appointment of a person as chief executive or chief operating officer of a company which is a recognized exchange controller shall have effect unless the appointment has the approval in writing of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission, after consultation with the Financial Secretary and the chairman of a recognized exchange controller, is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: it may, by notice in writing served on a person who is the chief executive or chief operating officer of the controller, remove the person from that office with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.content: A notice served under subsection (2) shall take effect immediately.

section.name: s71
section.heading: Production of records, etc. by recognized exchange controller

subsection.leadIn: The Commission may, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange controller, require the controller to provide to the Commission, within such period as the Commission may specify in the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: such books and records kept by it—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in connection with or for the purposes of its business;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in respect of any trading in securities or futures contracts traded on the stock market or futures market operated by the recognized exchange company of which it is a controller, or through the facilities of that company;

subparagraph.name: iia
subparagraph.content: in respect of any trading in OTC derivative products traded through the facilities of the recognized exchange company of which it is a controller; or (Added 6 of 2014 s. 8)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in respect of any clearing and settlement arrangements for any transactions in securities, futures contracts or OTC derivative products cleared or settled through the facilities of the recognized clearing house of which it is a controller; and (Amended 6 of 2014 s. 8)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such other information relating to its business or any such trading or clearing and settlement arrangements,

subsection.continued: as the Commission may reasonably require for the performance of its functions.

subsection.content: A recognized exchange controller served with a notice under subsection (1) which, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s72
section.heading: Withdrawal of recognition of exchange controller

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), where the Commission is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the proper regulation of markets in securities or futures contracts,

subsection.continued: it may, with the consent in writing of the Financial Secretary, by notice in writing served on a recognized exchange controller stating the reasons in support of the ground or grounds for the notice—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: withdraw the company’s recognition as an exchange controller with effect from a date specified in the notice for the purpose; or

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.leadIn: direct the company to take such steps as are specified in the notice—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: for the purpose of causing the company to cease to be such controller; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: within such period as is specified in the notice for the purpose.

subsection.content: The Commission shall not exercise its power under subsection (1) in relation to a recognized exchange controller unless it has given the controller a reasonable opportunity of being heard.

Without limiting the generality of steps referred to in subsection (1)(ii) which may be specified in a notice under that subsection to be served on a company referred to in that subsection, such steps may consist in whole or in part of steps proposed in writing to the Commission by that company.

The steps specified in a notice under subsection (1)(ii) may be framed so as to afford the company on which the notice is served a choice between different ways of ceasing to be a controller of the recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house concerned.
Where the Commission withdraws a company’s recognition as an exchange controller under subsection (1)(i), it shall cause notice of that fact to be published in the Gazette.

subsection.leadIn: A notice served under subsection (1) shall not take effect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), until the expiration of the period within which an appeal against the notice may be made under section 73; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if an appeal against the notice is made under section 73, until the appeal is withdrawn, abandoned or determined.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (8), a company served with a notice under subsection (1) which fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (7) to prove that the person exercised reasonable diligence to comply with the notice concerned under subsection (1) served on the person.

Where a company served with a notice under subsection (1) fails to comply with the notice (and whether or not the company is charged with an offence under subsection (7) in relation to the failure), the provisions of Part 6 of Schedule 3 shall immediately apply.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Appeals

subsection.content: A person served with a notice under section 59(9)(c), 61(9)(b), 70(2), 72(1) or 75(1) may appeal against the notice to the Chief Executive in Council not later than 14 days after the date of service of the notice or such longer period (if any) as the Commission specifies in the notice.
The decision of the Chief Executive in Council on an appeal under subsection (1) shall be final.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Provisions applicable where recognized exchange controller, etc. seeks to be listed corporation

subsection.leadIn: A relevant recognized exchange controller, or a relevant corporation, shall not become a listed corporation unless and until the Commission states in writing that it is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), rules made under section 23 adequately deal with possible conflicts of interest that might arise if the relevant recognized exchange controller or relevant corporation (as the case may be) were to be a listed corporation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the relevant recognized exchange controller or relevant corporation (as the case may be) has entered into arrangements with the Commission that adequately ensure—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the integrity of the market in securities or futures contracts traded on the stock market or futures market operated by the recognized exchange company concerned or through the facilities of that recognized exchange company; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the compliance with obligations as a listed corporation which would fall on the relevant recognized exchange controller or relevant corporation (as the case may be) if it were to become a listed corporation.

subsection.content: Rules referred to in subsection (1)(a) shall make provision to the effect that the Commission shall, instead of the Stock Exchange Company, take all actions and make all decisions in relation to the relevant recognized exchange controller or relevant corporation that would be taken by the Stock Exchange Company in the case of a corporation that was neither a recognized exchange controller nor a relevant corporation except in the case of any action or decision in respect of which the Commission states in writing that it is satisfied that a conflict of interest will not arise if that action or decision were to be taken or made (as the case may be) by the Stock Exchange Company.

subsection.leadIn: By virtue of this section, the Commission shall have such functions as are provided for it under—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rules made for the purposes of subsections (1)(a) and (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: arrangements referred to in subsection (1)(b).

subsection.content: Where a fee is payable to the Stock Exchange Company by a person for the taking of an action or the making of a decision which may be taken or made (as the case may be) by the Commission by virtue of subsections (1)(a) and (2), then, notwithstanding any other enactment or rule of law, that person shall pay that fee to the Commission in any case where the Commission takes that action or makes that decision (as the case may be) by virtue of those subsections.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Commission may give directions to recognized exchange controller where it is satisfied that conflict of interest exists, etc.

subsection.leadIn: Where the Commission is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a conflict of interest exists or may come into existence between—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the interest of a recognized exchange controller or a relevant corporation; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the interest of the proper performance of the functions conferred by this or any other Ordinance (including any rules made under any Ordinance, whether or not they are subsidiary legislation) on the controller or the relevant corporation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: such a conflict of interest has existed in circumstances that make it likely that the conflict of interest will continue or be repeated,

subsection.continued: then the Commission may, by notice in writing served on the controller or relevant corporation (as the case may be) stating the reasons in support of the ground or grounds for the notice, direct the controller or relevant corporation (as the case may be) to forthwith take such steps as are specified in the notice (including steps in relation to any of its affairs, business and property whatsoever) for the purposes of remedying the conflict of interest or the matters occasioning the conflict of interest (as the case may be).

subsection.content: A notice served under subsection (1) shall take effect immediately.

subsection.leadIn: A recognized exchange controller or relevant corporation served with a notice under subsection (1) which, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with the notice commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s76
section.heading: Fees to be approved by Commission

subsection.leadIn: No fee imposed on or after the commencement of this section by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a recognized exchange controller in its capacity as a recognized exchange controller; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: of which the recognized exchange controller is a controller; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in its capacity as a recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be),

subsection.continued: shall have effect unless the fee is specified in the rules of the recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house (as the case may be) and has the approval in writing of the Commission.

subsection.leadIn: The Commission shall, in deciding whether or not to approve a fee referred to in subsection (1), have regard to, among other matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the level of competition (if any) in Hong Kong for the matter for which the fee is to be imposed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the level of fee (if any) imposed by another recognized exchange controller, recognized exchange company or recognized clearing house or any similar body outside Hong Kong, for the same or a similar matter to which the fee relates.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Financial Secretary may appoint not more than 8 persons to board of directors of HKEC

subsection.content: Notwithstanding any enactment or rule of law but subject to subsection (2), the Financial Secretary may appoint not more than 8 persons to be members of the board of directors of the HKEC where the Financial Secretary is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in the interest of the investing public or in the public interest.

The Financial Secretary shall exercise his power under subsection (1) in such a way that immediately following the annual general meeting of the HKEC held in 2003 and thereafter, the number of members of its board of directors who are such members by virtue of an appointment under that subsection is not more than the maximum number of members of that board who may be such members otherwise than by virtue of such an appointment (but excluding the chief executive of the HKEC).

Subject to subsection (4), a member of the board of directors of the HKEC who is such a member by virtue of an appointment under subsection (1) shall have the same rights, privileges, obligations and liabilities under any enactment or rule of law as a member of that board who is such a member otherwise than by virtue of such an appointment.

Notwithstanding any enactment or rule of law, no person appointed under subsection (1) as a member of the board of directors of the HKEC may be removed from that office by a resolution of the other directors of the board or a special resolution of the HKEC.

subsection.def: In this section, HKEC (交易結算公司) means the company incorporated, and registered by the name Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, under the relevant Ordinance. (Amended 28 of 2012 ss. 912 & 920)

section.name: s78
section.heading: Amendment of Schedule 3
section.content: The Chief Executive in Council may, by order published in the Gazette, amend Parts 2, 3, 4, 6, 7 or 8 of Schedule 3.

section.name: s79
section.heading: Recognition of investor compensation company
